<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GOVERNMENT
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/05/corporations-have-mostly-kept-their-pledges-to-withdraw-financial-support-for-election-objectors?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">
<font color="#000000">
Corporations (Mostly) Keep Their 1/6 Pledges
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/05/corporations-have-mostly-kept-their-pledges-to-withdraw-financial-support-for-election-objectors?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="">
<img alt="Capitol Hill " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/ba93cdeb9b49fcf4ddf9eece8d4af88699a32f4f-1024x683.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Al Drago/Getty Images</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">One year ago today, hundreds of supporters of former President Trump attacked the US Capitol building in an attempt to overturn the results of the free and fair 2020 presidential election.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">They weren’t the only ones attempting to decertify the election: After the attack had been subdued, 147 Republican members of Congress (139 members of the House and eight senators) voted to overturn the election results in Pennsylvania, Arizona, or both states.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Not wanting to be associated with the dismantling of democracy, major corporations in the US condemned the violence and affirmed the peaceful transition of power that’s stood as the hallmark of American governance. Many went further, pledging to stop donations to the election objectors or pause political giving altogether.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">It’s January 6, 2022. What’s the update?</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Surprise—corporations have <em>mostly</em> kept their commitments and significantly drawn down their giving to the objectors. An <a href="https://popular.info/p/the-truth-about-corporate-contributions?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">analysis</a> by Popular Information found that corporate political action committee (PAC) contributions to those lawmakers fell by nearly two-thirds compared to the 2019 election cycle.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Another <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2022/01/05/corporations-jan-6-republicans/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">investigation</a> by the Washington Post revealed that the share of Fortune 500 PACs that donated to the GOP objectors had dropped from 60% to 20% in the first six months of 2021, compared to the same period in 2017.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But while corporate giving to these lawmakers has slowed, it’s far from stopped altogether. 717 corporations and industry groups funneled <a href="https://www.citizensforethics.org/reports-investigations/crew-reports/the-corporate-insurrection-how-companies-have-broken-promises-and-funded-seditionists/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew#top-corp-donors" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">more than $18 million</a> to 143 members of Congress who voted to decertify the elections, according to the ethics watchdog Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington (CREW). The top corporate donors to the objectors and their party committees were Boeing ($346,500), Koch Industries ($308,000), and American Crystal Sugar ($285,000).</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">All eyes on 2022</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As political campaigns rev up for the midterm elections this fall, corporations will be under even more scrutiny to back up their “I <3 democracy” statements with their donation choices. Seven major US companies, including Airbnb, Lyft, BASF, and Microsoft, have said they <a href="https://popular.info/p/seven-major-corporations-pledge-not?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">won’t contribute</a> to the GOP objectors this election cycle, per Popular Information. The rest? Well, we’ll find out.—<em>NF</em></p>
</div>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPORTS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/05/Novak-Djokovic-declined-visa-Australian-Open?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">
<font color="#000000">
Australia Doesn't Get the Djok
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/05/Novak-Djokovic-declined-visa-Australian-Open?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="">
<img alt="Novak Djokovic" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/7fd7d90109f8e89381f9b447e5c01a77d266b5f1-5126x3429.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Clive Brunskill/Getty Images</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Imagine flying 14 hours from Dubai to Melbourne, being questioned by border officials overnight, then told you have to fly back home.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That’s what happened to Novak Djokovic on Thursday. While on his way to compete in the Australian Open later this month, the No. 1 ranked tennis player’s visa to enter the country was <a href="https://www.abc.net.au/news/2022-01-06/novak-djokovic-visa-rejected-in-melbourne-australian-open/100740812?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">rejected</a> by the Australian government, throwing his quest to win a record 21st major title in serious doubt.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory: </strong>Djokovic, who has previously said he’s opposed to Covid vaccines, was granted a <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/01/05/sports/tennis/djokovic-vaccine-exemption-australian-open.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">medical exemption</a> by the tournament’s organizers so he could compete. But clearly they didn’t run that decision by government officials, who said Djokovic hadn’t provided evidence to meet Australia’s entry requirements.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>That Djokovic was allowed to play in the first place was greeted with a torrent of criticism by lockdown-weary Australians, who accused the tennis star of receiving preferential treatment. Meanwhile, people in Djokovic’s native Serbia are also upset over the situation, but in defense of Djokovic. President Aleksandar Vucic wrote that Serbian authorities are taking steps to halt the “harassment of the best tennis player in the world.”—<em>NF</em></p>
</div>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FOOD & BEV
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/usda-rebrands-gmo-food-label-bioengineered?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">
<font color="#000000">
A GMO by Any Other Name
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/usda-rebrands-gmo-food-label-bioengineered?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="">
<img alt="robot made of lettuce with tomato ears." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/84bc9fc28d593bc8a148f3f2f642d09e3aa8d16b-1500x1000.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em><em>Francis Scialabba</em></em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The USDA has only one New Year’s resolution, and it’s to make you learn new food labels. Starting Jan. 1, foods containing GMOs—ie., ones that have been subject to genetic manipulation to improve their quality, like corn that’s resistant to pests or watermelons shaped like Mount Rushmore—will now require a “<a href="https://www.npr.org/2022/01/05/1070212871/usda-bioengineered-food-label-gmo?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">bioengineered</a>” label.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The goal:</strong> Do away with the succotash of state regulations for GMOs and standardize labels across the country.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But just like when a surprise Catan rule change is implemented after all the settlements have been placed, many players are frustrated. Food companies say the timing couldn’t be worse given ongoing supply-chain issues. And advocacy groups like the Center for Food Safety say the new labeling requirement creates too many loopholes and puts an undue burden on consumers.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">But it might not make much of a difference. </strong>A recent <a href="https://www.fooddive.com/news/gmo-labeling-not-likely-to-impact-purchase-decisions-study-says/616452/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">study</a> by Cornell researchers found that mandatory labeling doesn’t really change the rate at which consumers purchase products containing GMOs.<em>—MM</em></p>
</div>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">You deserve better coffee, faster. <p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It starts with Cometeer<span class="s1">‘s </span>custom-built brewing system that optimizes for variables like grind size and water chemistry. Liquefy the frozen deliciousness into a cup of water or milk, hot or iced, and voilà; <strong style="color:#000">melting is the new making.</strong> No equipment necessary. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">So whether you’re in your kitchen or enjoying the great outdoors, you can have phenomenal coffee in seconds. Just be prepared to look like you’re from the future.</p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GRAB BAG
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/05/key-performance-indicators-january-6?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">
<font color="#000000">
Key Performance Indicators
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>After canceling almost 1,500 US flights yesterday, airlines have now scrapped more than 1,000 flights for <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/airlines-cancel-more-than-1-000-flights-for-11th-straight-day-11641404452?mod=hp_lista_pos1" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">11 straight days</a>, the worst stretch since they cut nearly 33% of all flights at the beginning of the pandemic. They’re blaming nasty winter weather plus staff shortages due to Omicron.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote: </strong>“The unvaccinated, I really want to piss them off.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">With new Covid cases smashing records in the country, French President Emmanuel Macron bluntly stated that, if you’re unvaccinated, he wants to <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/01/05/world/macron-france-life-miserable-unvaccinated.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">make your life miserable</a>. Those comments drew intense criticism from other French politicians at a time when the government is trying to pass a bill that would bar France’s 5 million unvaccinated people from participating in basic social events like going to a restaurant.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Read: </strong>Ethereum has a gas problem. (<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/ethereum-gas-fees?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Morning Brew</a>)</p>
</div>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TECH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/CES-2022-best-tech-announcements?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">
<font color="#000000">
The Coolest Tech Announced at CES This Week
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/CES-2022-best-tech-announcements?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="">
<img alt="Chevy Silverado EV" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/ac84e8ee54962833301803595eba8fcbd78017bb-1080x631.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Chevrolet</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Covid be darned, CES is actually happening in-person this Wednesday through Friday in Las Vegas. Though some of the biggest names in tech (Amazon, Google, Meta) stayed home due to Omicron concerns, that didn’t stop companies from debuting gadgets that ranged from downright useful to unnecessary-but-fun at the annual tech trade show.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Here’s a shortlist:</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The Chevy Silverado, but electric:</strong> The Ford F-150 Lightning is getting <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2022/1/5/22863648/chevy-silverado-electric-truck-specs-price?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">some competition</a> from GM as the epic auto rivalry enters the EV age.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">While we’re talking travel: </strong>Hyundai announced an autonomous <a href="https://www.multivu.com/players/English/8998251-hhi-group-smart-shipping-mobility-ces/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">luxury ship</a> and plans to make a self-driving cargo ship, so we can blame robots when it gets stuck in a canal.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The microest of climates: </strong>Shiftall’s <a href="https://en.shiftall.net/products/pebblefeel?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Pebble Feel</a> device straps onto your back and, when paired with a special shirt or belt, can make the wearer feel temperatures ranging from 48- to 107 degrees Fahrenheit. Perfect if you’re in a thermostat war or for playing virtual reality games.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">For never getting off the couch: </strong>The <a href="https://labradorsystems.com/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Labrador Retriever</a> is a nightstand-shaped robot that ferries items around your home, and it can slide food from the fridge straight to you. Great for lazy folks, but even more exciting for those in assisted living facilities.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The rest:</strong> Color-changing <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2022/1/5/22867090/bmw-color-changing-paint-electric-car-ces?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">car paint</a> from BMW, a jaw-shaped <a href="https://y-brush.com/en?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">toothbrush</a> that does the job in ten seconds, Prinker’s digital temporary <a href="https://www.prinker.us/products/prinker-m?gclid=Cj0KCQiAoNWOBhCwARIsAAiHnEiLygak-w5NWyklvcBKZIBNglu8m_ZzP6h-ZMuDcoOaseUOg9Nta4caAnQEEALw_wcB" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">tattoo printer</a>, and a <a href="https://mybirdbuddy.com/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">smart bird feeder</a> for impatient birders.<em>—JW</em></p>
</div>

<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Brew Mini: </strong>Our puzzle creator Mary Tobler cooked up another great Mini for you this morning. <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/05/brew-mini-rep?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Play it here</a>.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Three Headlines and a Lie</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Three of these news headlines are real and one is faker than a “Hope you had a good holiday!” message from your boss. Can you guess the odd one out?</p>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>‘90 Day Fiance’ star who made £38,000 a week selling farts in a jar </span><span><a href="https://metro.co.uk/2022/01/04/90-day-fiance-star-selling-farts-in-a-jar-for-38k-a-week-hospitalised-15863914/?ito=socialmetrouktwitter" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">hospitalized</a></span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>A Portland couple won a bidding war for a million-dollar home by throwing in a set of </span><span><a href="https://media.giphy.com/media/1XSKgue3C7Oow/giphy.gif?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">super-rare cookbooks</a></span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Opting for pets over children is selfish and ‘takes away our humanity,’ </span><span><a href="https://www.cnn.com/2022/01/05/europe/pope-dogs-cats-kids-intl/index.html?utm_content=2022-01-05T18%3A35%3A07&utm_term=link&utm_source=twCNN&utm_medium=social" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">says</a></span><span> Pope Francis</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Abducted son finds family by </span><span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/03/abducted-son-li-jingwei-finds-family-map-of-village-china?utm_source=nextdraft&utm_medium=email" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">drawing</a></span><span> map of village he last saw aged four</span>
</li>
</ol>

color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nCorporations (Mostly) Keep Their 1/6 Pledges \n\u003c/font\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ca collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOne year ago today, hundreds of supporters of former President Trump attacked the US Capitol building in an attempt to overturn the results of the free and fair 2020 presidential election.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThey weren’t the only ones attempting to decertify the election: After the attack had been subdued, 147 Republican members of Congress (139 members of the House and eight senators) voted to overturn the election results in Pennsylvania, Arizona, or both states.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNot wanting to be associated with the dismantling of democracy, major corporations in the US condemned the violence and affirmed the peaceful transition of power that’s stood as the hallmark of American governance. Many went further, pledging to stop donations to the election objectors or pause political giving altogether.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eIt’s January 6, 2022. What’s the update?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSurprise—corporations have \u003cem\u003emostly\u003c/em\u003e kept their commitments and significantly drawn down their giving to the objectors. An \u003ca href=\"https://popular.info/p/the-truth-about-corporate-contributions?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eanalysis\u003c/a\u003e by Popular Information found that corporate political action committee (PAC) contributions to those lawmakers fell by nearly two-thirds compared to the 2019 election cycle.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAnother \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2022/01/05/corporations-jan-6-republicans/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003einvestigation\u003c/a\u003e by the Washington Post revealed that the share of Fortune 500 PACs that donated to the GOP objectors had dropped from 60% to 20% in the first six months of 2021, compared to the same period in 2017.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut while corporate giving to these lawmakers has slowed, it’s far from stopped altogether. 717 corporations and industry groups funneled \u003ca href=\"https://www.citizensforethics.org/reports-investigations/crew-reports/the-corporate-insurrection-how-companies-have-broken-promises-and-funded-seditionists/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew#top-corp-donors\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emore than $18 million\u003c/a\u003e to 143 members of Congress who voted to decertify the elections, according to the ethics watchdog Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington (CREW). The top corporate donors to the objectors and their party committees were Boeing ($346,500), Koch Industries ($308,000), and American Crystal Sugar ($285,000).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eAll eyes on 2022\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAs political campaigns rev up for the midterm elections this fall, corporations will be under even more scrutiny to back up their “I \u003c3 democracy” statements with their donation choices. Seven major US companies, including Airbnb, Lyft, BASF, and Microsoft, have said they \u003ca href=\"https://popular.info/p/seven-major-corporations-pledge-not?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewon’t contribute\u003c/a\u003e to the GOP objectors this election cycle, per Popular Information. The rest? Well, we’ll find out.—\u003cem\u003eNF\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eImagine flying 14 hours from Dubai to Melbourne, being questioned by border officials overnight, then told you have to fly back home.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThat’s what happened to Novak Djokovic on Thursday. While on his way to compete in the Australian Open later this month, the No. 1 ranked tennis player’s visa to enter the country was \u003ca href=\"https://www.abc.net.au/news/2022-01-06/novak-djokovic-visa-rejected-in-melbourne-australian-open/100740812?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erejected\u003c/a\u003e by the Australian government, throwing his quest to win a record 21st major title in serious doubt.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backstory: \u003c/strong\u003eDjokovic, who has previously said he’s opposed to Covid vaccines, was granted a \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/01/05/sports/tennis/djokovic-vaccine-exemption-australian-open.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emedical exemption\u003c/a\u003e by the tournament’s organizers so he could compete. But clearly they didn’t run that decision by government officials, who said Djokovic hadn’t provided evidence to meet Australia’s entry requirements.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eThat Djokovic was allowed to play in the first place was greeted with a torrent of criticism by lockdown-weary Australians, who accused the tennis star of receiving preferential treatment. Meanwhile, people in Djokovic’s native Serbia are also upset over the situation, but in defense of Djokovic. President Aleksandar Vucic wrote that Serbian authorities are taking steps to halt the “harassment of the best tennis player in the world.”—\u003cem\u003eNF\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe USDA has only one New Year’s resolution, and it’s to make you learn new food labels. Starting Jan. 1, foods containing GMOs—ie., ones that have been subject to genetic manipulation to improve their quality, like corn that’s resistant to pests or watermelons shaped like Mount Rushmore—will now require a “\u003ca href=\"https://www.npr.org/2022/01/05/1070212871/usda-bioengineered-food-label-gmo?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebioengineered\u003c/a\u003e” label.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe goal:\u003c/strong\u003e Do away with the succotash of state regulations for GMOs and standardize labels across the country.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut just like when a surprise Catan rule change is implemented after all the settlements have been placed, many players are frustrated. Food companies say the timing couldn’t be worse given ongoing supply-chain issues. And advocacy groups like the Center for Food Safety say the new labeling requirement creates too many loopholes and puts an undue burden on consumers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBut it might not make much of a difference. \u003c/strong\u003eA recent \u003ca href=\"https://www.fooddive.com/news/gmo-labeling-not-likely-to-impact-purchase-decisions-study-says/616452/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003estudy\u003c/a\u003e by Cornell researchers found that mandatory labeling doesn’t really change the rate at which consumers purchase products containing GMOs.\u003cem\u003e—MM\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\"
